entry.title: Understanding SAP Batch Management ‚Äì A Simple and Practical Guide - Part 1.
entry.content:
The purpose of this blog is to explain the concept of  Batch Management in SAP in a simple and easy-to-understand manner. Many consultants and end users face confusion during batch configuration and usage, especially when it comes to understanding when and how batches are created and determined. This post aims to clarify those concepts step by step.

Overview of Batch Management

Batch Management in SAP can broadly be divided into  two main areas:

1. Batch Creation
2. Batch Determination

 

Understanding the difference between these two is key to working effectively with batches in SAP.

1. Batch Creation:

Batch creation generally takes place at the time of product receipt, such as during Goods Receipt (GR). A batch can be created in two ways:

  1. Automatically by the system during Goods Receipt
  2. Manually by the user and then assigned to the material

If batch management is activated for a material in the material master, SAP can automatically create a batch during goods receipt.

2. Batch Determination:

Batch determination is typically involved at the time of product issue, for example:

  • Goods Issue against a movement type
  • Sales Order processing
  • Production Order consumption

Batch determination allows the system to automatically select the appropriate batch based on predefined criteria.

Classification and Its Role in Batch Management

For simple batch creation, it is not mandatory to assign classification in the material master. However, if you want:

  •  Automatic batch determination during Goods Issue, and/or
  • To store and use batch-specific information (such as expiry date, vendor batch number, or quality attributes),

then classification must be maintained in the material master.

Key Points to Note:

Without classification:

  • Batches can be created
  • No batch-specific characteristics can be stored
  • Automatic batch determination is not possible

With classification:

  • Batch characteristics are captured at the time of batch creation
  • System can automatically determine the batch during Goods Issue based on characteristic values

If you do not require automatic batch determination or batch-specific characteristic data, then classification maintenance is not required in the material master.

For only creating batches, the below configuration activities are sufficient.

1. Batch Levels in SAP

Batch levels define how batch numbers are managed across materials and plants in SAP.

Configuration Path: SPRO ‚Üí Logistics ‚Äì General ‚Üí Batch Management ‚Üí Specify Batch Level and Activate Status Management ‚Üí Batch Level

SAP On-Premises system supports three batch levels:

a. Client Level

  • Each material will always have a unique batch number across the entire client.
  • The same batch number cannot be reused for another material.

b. Plant Level

  • Different materials within the same plant can share the same batch number.
  • The same material in different plants can also have the same batch number.

c. Material Level

  • The same batch number can be used for the same material across multiple plants, provided the specifications are the same.

2. Batch Number Assignment

Configuration Path: SPRO ‚Üí Logistics ‚Äì General ‚Üí Batch Management ‚Üí Batch Number Assignment

Once batch management is activated at the configuration level, you must also, enable the Batch Management indicator in the Material Master.

This setup is sufficient for automatic batch number creation during goods receipt.

However, without classification you cannot store batch-specific data. The same will be helpful at the time of batch determination.

If you want to capture and manage batch-specific information, you must maintain Batch Classification (Class Type 023).

Example Scenario

Assume you want to capture the Vendor Batch Number for each incoming material.

Steps Involved:

1. Create Characteristics using transaction CT04

Example: Vendor Batch Number

2. Create a Class using transaction CL01

Class Type: 023 (Batch Class)

3. Assign the Class to the Material Master

Maintain this under the Classification View of the material master

Once this setup is complete:

  • Batch numbers will be created automatically during Goods Receipt
  • Batch-specific information can be captured and stored
  • System can perform automatic batch determination during Goods Issue based on characteristic values

Conclusion

Batch Management becomes much easier once the concepts of batch creation, batch determination, and classification are clearly understood. Not every scenario requires complex configuration‚Äîclassification and batch determination should only be implemented when business requirements demand batch-specific tracking and automatic selection.

In the upcoming blog, I will explain Automatic Batch Determination in detail, including configuration steps, master data requirements, and real-time business scenarios to help you understand how SAP automatically selects batches during Goods Issue and other processes.

entry.title: BAPI :FINDING AND TESTING
entry.content:
INTRODUCTION:

Functional consultants need to use bapi's  when it is not possible to meet client requirements with standard screens.

This blogg is useful to give A general idea about finding bapi's and also to test them.

BAPI

BAPI(Business Application Programming Interface) is a business-level programming interface provided by SAP to execute standard business processes in a controlled and validated way.

In short they simulate the business logic behind the functional screens ,BAPI validate data before updating to tables so they reduce the risk of data corruption,

BAPI are used to connect sap system with non-sap system and also in developing custom  screens to meet the business requirement

HOW TO FIND BAPI‚ÄôS

Method:1

TCODE: BAPI

 

We can find bapis using bapi transaction and can search with respect to module.

Method2:

SE37

 

Search with *BAPI_* to find the bapi

 

Method3:

Just search in google or with ai.

 

IMPORTANT DETAILS REGARDING  BAPI

1.Please read the bapi documentation clearly. Sometimes  it will save lot of time

To find the documentation pass the bapi

Pass the bapi in se37 and click on display and then in new screen click on function module documentation

 

 

which fields  are mandatory?

 

In se37 after executing the bapi we get screen as below

 

The screen has  import parameters and tables.

To get clarity on mandatory fields.

Step1: read documentation it will sometimes have values related to import parameters.

Step2:

 

By following above path we can see  if fields are optional or mandatory and can also see default values

Similarly we can check for tables. if there is no optional tickmark its mandatory to pass values in that field or table .

We can take reference from standard screens on what data to pass as bapi replicate business logic behind standard screens.

 

TESTING BAPI

 

For most of the bapis , bapi transaction commit also need to be passed for changes  changes to reflect in system but there are few exceptions like BAPI_PRODORD_RELEASE where there is no need to commit.

After clicking on execute we are in first bapi

Pass the mandatory values

Then execute

Click on back button

Now we are in commit BAPI

Pass ‚ÄòX‚Äô  and execute

 

Click on back button again

RESULT:

Before executing BAPI

 

After executing BAPI

We can copy the test data to test data directory for future reference or to pass the test data to ABAP team.

To check the executed test data

 

Click on the record number we can check what data was passed.

CONCLUSION:

Please follow above steps for finding  bapi's and also to test them.

entry.title: How to Add Buffer for MTO Items Without Changing PDT or GR time
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I‚Äôm looking for guidance on how to manage transport variability for MTO items sourced from internal factories, without changing PDT, transport lanes, or GR time‚Äîand without negatively impacting KPIs or creating unintended behaviour at the supplying plant.

Current Setup

  • MTO materials use a PDT (Planned Delivery Time) of ~10 days.
  • GR processing time is 1 day.
  • When a customer places an order, the system commits a delivery on Day 12.

Issue

The actual deliveries from the internal factory regularly arrive 4‚Äì5 days late, usually due to transport variability (delays in the supply chain, logistics issues, etc.).

What I Tried

1. Increasing PDT (adding 4‚Äì5 day buffer)

This caused undesirable behaviour:

  • The supplying plant can see the customer requested date and knows the true transport time.
  • As a result, they delay their outbound shipments even more, because they still try to meet the customer‚Äôs requested date exactly.

So increasing PDT does not fix the issue.

2. Increasing transport times in the lane

Not possible.
Transport lanes are shared with MTS materials, and inflating the transport time would create overstock in MTS.

3. GR Buffer

Adding a GR buffer works technically but negatively impacts the DC KPI, making the DC appear late even when the problem is upstream.
So GR buffer is not acceptable.

What I‚Äôm Trying to Achieve

A way to add a buffer that absorbs transport variability, which:

  • Does not change PDT
  • Does not change GR processing time
  • Does not impact DC KPIs
  • Is not visible to the supplying plant
  • Still allows us to promise a realistic date to the customer

Possible Direction: ATP Buffer?

Is there a way to introduce an ATP-only buffer that adjusts what we promise to the customer, without affecting MRP or supplier visibility?

Example:

  • Customer order date: 01 Jan
  • MTO PDT: 10 days
  • GR time: 1 day
  • Normal ATP delivery date: 12 Jan
  • With an ATP buffer: commit 15 Jan to customer
    ‚Üí while keeping PDT/GR unchanged and not altering transport lanes.

Question

Is there an SAP configuration, ATP setting, or planning method that allows an invisible buffer for MTO items‚Äîone that does not modify PDT, GR time, or lane transit times, and does not impact KPIs?
Could ATP buffering or date‚Äëoffset logic be used here?
Any best practices for handling internal MTO transport variability?

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: Re: Effortless SAPUI5 Patch Management: Introducing the New SAPUI5 Runtime Repository
entry.content:
Hello @kirilin @matthias_schmalz ,
Great blog. Any improvements in the SAPUI5 space is always welcome
Maintaining SAPUI5 libraries on the ABAP stack has always been difficult and troublesome and more so for customers using Federated Content on SAP BTP/ WorkZone . (https://me.sap.com/notes/3440011)

Consider someone running S4 HANA 2023 with SAP_UI 758. 
The 'latest' version of SAPUI5 available for such a customer is 1.120.40 which gets deleted from CDN in Q1/2027 (no exact dates , assuming sometime in Q1/2027).
If the customer starts an update to this version and completes it in 3-4 months (including all the tests mandated by the organization and the process) -  he still has to start another update of the landscape within the next 3 months after completion of the 1st update and finish it before end of the year.

There still seems to be room for improvement in this general process of SAPUI5 updates for ABAP systems.
Wondering how different customers manage this ?

entry.title: FEBAN ‚Äì Handling Open Items Without SAP Document Numbers (MT940 Reconciliation Issue)
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

The client is facing an issue where several open items remain in FEBAN, even though bank reconciliation has already been completed for the previous month using MT940.

The situation is as follows:

  • The business made payments to vendors.

  • Due to some issue, those payments were reversed by the bank.

  • As a result, the bank statement contains pairs of transactions with the same amount:

    • One negative amount

    • One positive amount

  • There are around 50 such transaction pairs.

Key Observations

  • These transactions do not have SAP document numbers, as they were never posted in SAP.

  • Therefore, there is no GL impact from these entries.

  • However, these entries continue to appear as open items in FEBAN.

Business Concern

The client does not want these transactions to appear in the FEBAN open item list, because:

  • The open item list will continue to grow month by month.

  • This will make future bank reconciliation activities more difficult and time-consuming.

  • From a business perspective, these debit and credit entries net to zero and are already understood.

Proposed Solution (Based on My Analysis)

I have identified a possible solution and attached relevant screenshots for reference.
The idea is to complete these open items in FEBAN so that they do not appear in future reconciliation periods, even though they do not have SAP document numbers and no accounting impact.

Request to the Community

  • Is my identified solution the correct and recommended SAP approach?

  • Is there a standard SAP way to clear or manage such technical open items without posting FI documents?

  • Any suggestions, or best practice guidance would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: How to prepare server to use Sybase Adaptive Server Enterprise (ASE) Database for CMS - Linux OS
entry.content:
How to configure system to use Sybase ASE Database for CMS
Prerequisites to configure, before using Sybase ASE Database for CMS

Prerequisite before installing BI with Sybase ASE.

  • Get the database connection details from the Sybase Database Team.
  • We should have below details :
    • DB Host:Port
    • SID/Service_name
    • DB Account/password

Installing the Sybase ASE Client.

  • Download the Sybase ASE client from the software downloads.
  • Access https://me.sap.com/softwarecenter 
    • In the search box: SDK FOR SAP ASE
    • Download the same for LINUX ON X86_64 64 BIT


       

  • The File Downloaded would be like: SDKASE161000P_0-71008903.TGZ ( Assuming downloading for ASE 16.1)
  • Move the file to Linux Server on which you want to install.
  • Create an Directory to extract the installer
    • Unzip the SYBASE ASE client:  $ tar -xvzf SDKASE161000P_0-71008903.TGZ -C /<path you want to extract to>

  • Create one New Directory to install the extracted Sybase ASE installer. 
    • Run the setup.bin ( ./setup.bin)

       

    • Accept the License and then choose the PATH to install the installer:



    • Choose the installer type: 3 Custom



    • Select the Component number you don't want to install and separate by comma.

    • Below is the features that are going to get installed : 



    • Ready to Install, to confirm the location: 



    • Installation completed :



    • Once installation is done, we would see below directory structure:


Setting the Environment Variable, POST Installation of Sybase ASE Client.

  •  The details to set environment variable would be present in the the SYBASE.env file.

Below is the SAMPLE that need to be set in the user bash profile.

export SAP_JRE8=/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT/shared/SAPJRE-8_1_102_64BIT
export SAP_JRE8_64=/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT/shared/SAPJRE-8_1_102_64BIT
export SYBASE_OCS=OCS-16_1
export INCLUDE=/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT/OCS-16_1/include:$INCLUDE
export LIB=/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT/OCS-16_1/lib:$LIB
export PATH=/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT/OCS-16_1/bin:$PATH
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT/OCS-16_1/lib:/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT/OCS-16_1/lib3p64:/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT/OCS-16_1/lib3p:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
export SYBASE=/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT/DataAccess/ODBC/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT/DataAccess64/ODBC/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
export SYBROOT=/build/XXXX/SYBASECLIENT

 

POST setting the Environment Variable : Configuring the interfaces / Connectivity to the Sybase ASE Database.

 

  • Create a new File named interfaces under $SYBASE directory.
  • Provide proper right to the file.
  • In the file do below entry :

    ServiceName/SID
                master TCP ether <Sybase_ASE_DB_HOST> <PORT>
                query TCP ether <Sybase_ASE_DB_HOST> <PORT>

  • Make sure that after the ServiceName/SID on the second line, Press TAB key to align. Similarly for the 3rd Line.
  • Also After the Sybase host there is space

Checking Connectivity using isql

  • Running below command from bash/ shell  :
     isql -S <ServiceName/SID> -U <username> -P <Password>
     ex: isql -S Sample -U SampleUser -P Password
  • If isql command is not getting recognized, it means the environment variable has not been set correctly.

entry.title: From insight to impact: The future of planning with SAP agent driven experiences
entry.content:
Planning is evolving.  Fast.
Static models and endless spreadsheets aren‚Äôt enough anymore.

entry.title: Re: Verify database accessing
entry.content:
Hi,

"oracle database 10.2 running with SAP kernel 721 has the encryption" is not necessarily true, there is no encryption by default. And there are different kind of encryption from database level, so it would be important to know what kind of encryption the consultant meant. Like, "network encrption" from SAP note ##973450, or Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) from SAP notes ##973450,##974876.
In regards to SSFS, it is not a encyrption but rather a more secure connection type for the SAP System, because SAP workprocesses (including R3trans and some other SAP tools) can use a secure connection method to get the user and password (encrypted by SAP workprocesses) to connect to the database. The availability of SSFS connection method depends on the SAP Kernel (so also indirectly depends on the SAP System) , like mentioned in SAP note ##1639578. In case the SAP System Kernel meats the criteria you can use ABAP SSFS instead of the regular and outdated OPS$ mechanism. In this case just follow the SAP note ##1639578.

entry.content:
Hi,

Task: Connect SquirrelSQL 5.0 or DBeaver via the aseuserstore to ASE 16.1 SP00 PL01.

1) SAIP entry created in aseuserstore:

C:\SAP\OCS-16_1\bin>aseuserstore.exe list

KEY: AMC_H2_FILE_PASSWORD
CON_ENV : local
USERNAME : H2SA
PASSWORD : ***
DATABASE : amc

KEY: AMC_H2_USER_PASSWORD
CON_ENV : local
USERNAME : H2SA
PASSWORD : ***
DATABASE : amc

KEY: SAIP
CON_ENV : jdbc:sybase:Tds:HP450RK:5000
USERNAME : sa
PASSWORD : ***

2) In SquirrelSQL create an Alias without username and password:
Name: AUSJDBC
Driver: Sybase Adaptive Server Enterprise
URL: jdbc:sybase:Tds:?SECURE_STORE_KEY=SAIP

3) Connecting to ASE fails:

Unexpected Error occurred attempting to open an SQL connection.
class java.net.UnknownHostException: jdbc:sybase:Tds:HP450RK

Changing the hostname to an IP address results in the same error; the IP address then appears at the end of the error message.
Adding the driver property SECURE_STORE_KEY to SquirrelSQL with the value SAIP results in the same error.
Connecting to the same driver without using the aseuserstore works without any issues. URL=jdbc:sybase:Tds:HP450RK:5000 and providing username and password .

entry.title: Re: AA347 Error When Posting MIRO in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ‚Äì...
entry.content:
Why this happens is because, in Private Cloud / On-Premise S/4HANA, the classic AJRW (Fiscal Year Change) transaction is technically replaced by FAA_CMP. If the fiscal year in table T093C (LGJAHR) is stuck in 2025, it means the Asset Accounting fiscal year change hasn‚Äôt been executed, even though FI has already closed 2025. That mismatch blocks postings (error AA347).

Perform the below steps

Run Fiscal Year Change for Asset Accounting
Go to transaction: FAA_CMP, Enter company code XXXX and fiscal year 2026 and save. This updates T093C.LGJAHR to 2026.

Check OAAQ
After FAA_CMP, go to OAAQ, verify that the fiscal year for company code XXXX now shows 2026.

Prerequisites
Ensure AJAB (Year-End Closing) has been completed for 2025. Ensure OB52 posting periods are open for 2026. Confirm depreciation runs for 2025 are finished.

entry.title: Re: Auto-approve step in flexible workflow for supplier i...
entry.content:
Below are the options for automatic first-step approval

Workflow Condition Configuration
In the Manage Workflows for Supplier Invoices app, you can define conditions where the workflow outcome is ‚ÄúRelease Automatically‚Äù. Example, for invoices blocked due to price variance but belonging to a specific PO category, set the condition so that the workflow auto-releases without routing to a user. This avoids the need for a dummy approver. Of course, defining conditions is not a free‚Äëform condition you configure yourself. Instead, you set up condition‚Äëbased workflows (e.g., invoice amount, company code, supplier group, blocking reason) and then choose the outcome as either ‚ÄúRelease Automatically‚Äù or ‚ÄúSend for Approval

Automatic Agent Determination
You can assign the system user (WF-BATCH) or a technical user as the agent for the first step. This way, the step is technically ‚Äúapproved‚Äù immediately without human intervention. This is the closest equivalent to a ‚Äúdummy approver.‚Äù

BAdI Implementation
SAP provides the BAdI Determine Workflow Agents for Supplier Invoice. You could implement logic that, for your specific PO category, returns a technical user as the approver. Since that user doesn‚Äôt require manual action, the step completes automatically. This is the recommended approach if you want fine-grained control.

entry.title: Re: how to process an old sto with quantity still to be d...
entry.content:
Below are the options to Clean Up

Reverse the Outbound Delivery (if possible)
If the goods issue was posted, use VL09 (Reversal of Goods Issue) to cancel the outbound. This will bring stock back into the delivering plant. Then you can either delete the STO line or close the STO.

Manually Post Goods Receipt in Receiving Plant
If the material physically moved and is already in the receiving plant, you can post a manual goods receipt (MIGO) against the STO. Even if the inbound delivery line was deleted, you can reference the STO directly in MIGO. This aligns stock without needing the inbound delivery line.

Close/Delete the STO Line
If the material was never received and you want to clean up, mark the STO line as final delivery or delete it. Reverse the outbound delivery so the delivering plant stock is corrected. This ensures no open commitments remain.

Use Transaction MBST/MBRL for Reversal
If the goods issue was posted, you can also use MBST (Cancel Material Document) or MBRL (Return Delivery) to reverse. This depends on whether you want to return stock or cancel the movement entirely.

Archiving Old STOs
Once inconsistencies are cleared (either by reversal or manual GR), you can archive old STOs using standard MM archiving objects. This removes them from open order reports.

entry.title: Re: A Wish for CLI-Based ABAP
entry.content:
I enjoyed this post, Mattias.

Ironically, when I first started working with SAP software, the code didn't live in the database, nor was it edited in Web browsers. First, the Web didn't exist back then, and second, this was R/2, where the code was S/370 assembler and lived in partitioned datasets, which we accessed via terminal-based facilities such as ISPF, and edited them in there too (typically using a ROSCOE-based editor). While there was a command line, this was in the TSO facility, but we lived in the panel-based ISPF world for most of the working day.

Anyway, I digress. I guess what I wanted to say is that I agree that managing source code as text, and using the power of the shell and command line based tools, is -- at least for me -- the ultimate in developer productivity, efficiency and power. I've long declared "The Future Is Terminal!" as a sort of tongue-in-cheek expression, but there is truth in that declaration too.

My working life has seen the assembler based SAP work, with batch jobs being the prominent method of execution, and JCL being (almost) as important as the assembler-based programs they managed, through the rise of ABAP and the monolith, with the inextricable link between database, code, and data dictionary, editors from TM38 thru SE38, SE80 (and siblings SE24 etc) and Eclipse + ADT, and now the desire to move back to the "dialtone" of text and command line, a dialtone that has persisted for over half a century in the form of Unix, a form that -- like it or not (and I do like it) -- is the very basis of our cloud environments.

entry.title: Impact on the processes
entry.content:
Hi Team,

If we do below configuration. What would be the impact:

  1. Define the plan categories for estimated costs, planned costs and baseline costs in Customizing of Controlling under General Controlling > Planning > Maintain Category for Planning. Define the three plan categories (e.g. PMORDER01, PMORDER02, PMORDER03) for the application type Maintenance Order and with No specific usage. Do not allow import, copy or delete.

  2. Define which of the three plan categories that you defined in the previous step is valid for estimated costs, which one for planned costs and which one for baseline costs. You can do this in Customizing for Controlling under General Controlling > Planning > Application-Specific Categories > Maintain Categories for Maintenance Orders. Note that you cannot change this assignment retrospectively.

Regards,

Jaya

entry.title: Re: 3451944 - FI PL : KSeF number enablement for MIRO pos...
entry.content:
If you followed all the 5 steps mentioned in the pdf attachment but still the issue of KSeF number disappears could be because if the field is visible but clears after entry, it usually means:

  • Field selection (OMR4) is set to ‚Äúsuppress‚Äù or not active.
  • The note transport didn‚Äôt fully activate the new structures.
  • The validation logic rejects the format (invalid UUID).

Please check the below areas

OMR4 (Field Selection for MIRO)
Ensure the new KSeF field is set to ‚Äúoptional‚Äù or ‚Äúrequired,‚Äù not ‚Äúsuppress.‚Äù

RBKP / BKPF structures
Verify the KSeF field exists in your system after note implementation.

Test with valid UUID
The Polish KSeF number is a 44‚Äëcharacter UUID. If you enter something shorter/invalid, the system clears it.

entry.title: Re: BAPI :FINDING AND TESTING
entry.content:
It seems to be a little repeating other blog posts like:

  • BAPI Simulation & Finding BAPI - SAP Community
  • How to Test BAPI Function Module in SAP? - SAP Community
  • How to Use FM - Inputs for BAPI_PROCORD_CREATE / B... - SAP Community (also includes Test Sequences)

To differentiate, you might write blog posts concerning aspects rarely discussed like:

  • Some BAPI function modules are not supported (sometimes, some BAPI have a specific SAP note mentioning it). SAP says that the supported ones are "Released to customers" (function module properties). Sometimes they are not released, or released only for SAP internal use, but can be used as explained in the SAP Notes. Otherwise, open a case to ask SAP Support.
  • Some BAPI function modules won't update the database if you run them via SE37, because a "Test Sequence" must be created in SE37 to run BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT after the BAPI. See the explanations in sap.com.

entry.title: Re: Street address is not displayed in the Billing docume...
entry.content:
Printing of street or P.O. box addresses-  default setting is P.O. box address - if available; otherwise street address is displayed.

In addition, users can vary the following parameters by Print Preview pushbutton in app "Maintain Business Partner" which has options like:

P PO Box has priority over street.

S Street has priority over PO Box.

entry.title: Re: Impact on the processes
entry.content:
Impact of this set up

Cost Storage & Reporting
Estimated costs, planned costs, and baseline costs will each be stored in their own dedicated plan category. Reports in CO (e.g. cost comparison, variance analysis) will pull values from these categories. This improves clarity because each type of cost has its own ‚Äúbucket.‚Äù

Integration with PM Orders
When you create or change a maintenance order, estimated costs (from order costing) go into PMORDER01. Planned costs (from manually planned activities/materials) go into PMORDER02. Baseline costs (reference snapshot for comparison) go into PMORDER03. This ensures consistency in how costs are tracked and compared.

Restrictions
Because you set ‚ÄúNo specific usage‚Äù and disallow import/copy/delete, these plan categories cannot be reused in other applications (e.g. projects, cost centers). They are locked to maintenance orders only. You cannot copy values between categories or import external plans into them.

Irreversibility
Once you assign PMORDER01/02/03 to estimated/planned/baseline in customizing, you cannot later reassign them to different roles. If you later decide you want a different plan category for ‚Äúplanned costs,‚Äù you would need to create new categories and reconfigure, but historical data would remain in the old ones. This has long-term reporting implications.

Reporting & Analytics
Standard CO reports (e.g. Order: Planned/Actual/Variance) will show values based on these categories. If you later want to consolidate or compare across applications, you may find these categories isolated. Custom reporting may be needed if you want to analyze across multiple plan categories.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Procure to Order 2602 Release Key Innovations
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Community, and welcome to our 2602 Key Innovations blog.
In this post, we‚Äôre sharing some key updates included in the Q1 2026 release in the procure to order space.

The focus this release covers flexibility in the Guided Buying RFQ process as well as ability to import contracts into SAP Ariba guided buying to help drive greater overall contract compliance and in turn more realised savings.

 

Use Standard Shipping Address for Request for Quotes in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-1267)

Based on the type of item and category, your organization may allow you to request a quote from one or more suppliers as the logical, stramlined process.

With this feature we have introduced more flexibility to select the ship-to address in the RFQ process in guided buying, you can now configure guided buying to either:

Display the user's default ship-to address on RFQ‚Äôs generated through guided buying (this is the default option)

Or

Allow users to choose an alternate shipping address for RFQ‚Äôs if better aligned to your companies processes

In order to do this a new parameter needs to be enabled by your system administrator: (PARAM_ENABLE_RFQ_SHIP_TO_ADDRESS_IN_USER_CHOSEN_ENTITY)

 

Import Purchase Contracts into SAP Ariba Buying Solutions  (ACC-267)

This feature enables buyers to import purchase contracts from SAP S/4HANA into SAP Ariba buying solutions as a customer configured option using the corresponding parameter ‚ÄòAutomatic approval of contract requests sent using web services‚Äô

In SAP Ariba buying solutions, you can publish non-catalog items in the contract compliance module, which generates subscriptions for those items to make them available in the catalog search to help drive contract compliance.

The import utilizes web services capability in SAP Integration Suite, Managed Gateway for Spend Management and SAP Business Network, which connects SAP S/4HANA and SAP Ariba buying solutions.

For more related technical information you can also refer to:

Integration Support to Import Purchase Contracts from SAP ERP to SAP Ariba Buying Solutions via Web Services

Automatic approval of contract requests sent using web services.

 

Enable Users to Join the SAP User Research Panel (GUIDEB-1259)

With this feature, respondents of the user experience survey in guided buying can provide additional feedback by joining the SAP User Research Panel.

This allows a continuous feedback mechanism where it‚Äôs needed, in the application.

This in turn will help SAP product teams to collect continuous feedback and further focus the innovation Roadmap where its important.

This feature introduces changes to the user experience survey. Now, after users complete the survey, a thank you message and an option to join the SAP User Research Panel displays.

 

We hope these features will provide a blend of enhancements that will help to streamline process, increase adoption and add valuable feedback channels into SAP Product. Thanks for reading.

 

Resources:

  • Feature related materials:
    • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
    • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
  • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
  • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement and Network
  • What‚Äôs New

entry.title: SBTi Forest, Land, and Agriculture (FLAG) in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management
entry.content:
As companies work towards meeting their climate targets, the distinction between fossil and land-based emissions is becoming increasingly relevant. Emissions from forests, land, and agriculture (FLAG) follow fundamentally different dynamics than those from fossil fuels and materials. FLAG emissions have a significant share in global greenhouse gas emissions, play a critical role in climate mitigation, biodiversity protection, and food system resilience, which provides several advantages in environmental impact mitigation within value chains.

However, these emissions are often bundled together with Fossil GHG Emissions within corporate inventories without the level of detail to credibly manage them. This makes it difficult for companies to set realistic targets, assess progress, or transparently communicate the role of land-based emissions and removals within their GHG inventories. 

When properly understood as part of the natural carbon cycle, FLAG emissions become an important part of net-zero strategies: They are governed by biological processes that allows them to interact directly with removals and carbon storage within shorter timeframes compared to Fossil emissions. 

Against this backdrop, the latest updates to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management mark a significant evolution from a single-impact focus to a holistic environmental footprint analysis. The new capabilities expand impact coverage and explicitly distinguish between fossil and biogenic emissions and removals, enabling companies to reflect land-based dynamics more accurately. 

 Why distinguishing FLAG emissions matters at corporate and product level 

Distinguishing FLAG emissions from Fossil emissions is not just an accounting exercise. At the corporate level, separating FLAG from non-FLAG emissions allows companies to determine whether they are required to set dedicated FLAG targets under certain criteria and to incorporate mitigation pathways that reflect the realities of land-based systems.  

At the Corporate level, this differentiation enables a more realistic target setting, prevents the inappropriate use or double counting of removals within corporate inventories, supports transparent reporting, and progress toward emissions reductions. Without this separation, land use impacts can get hidden behind corporate totals, making progress appear stronger than it actually is.

Within a corporate level inventory, consistently separating FLAG emissions within Scope 3 improves transparency, avoids misleading pictures of progress, and enables more comparable and credible reporting across companies and sectors. To do this, a value chain perspective is needed to ensure all FLAG emissions are accounted across upstream and downstream activities, in order to avoid the risk of them being lost into broader corporate emissions totals, making it difficult to apply removals appropriately or to reflect the distinct mitigation dynamics of land-based systems. This approach is especially important given the limited and evolving guidance on corporate-level inventories for agriculture, forestry, and other land-use (AFOLU) activities.  

At the product level, the distinction becomes even more critical. For many products, particularly agricultural commodities, food, apparel, and bio-based materials, land use change and land management emissions dominate the product's carbon footprint. Without clear FLAG attribution, product claims can become misleading; comparisons across suppliers and materials lose validity, and the climate benefits of bio-based materials or regenerative practices may be obscured. Explicit identification of FLAG emissions  is therefore essential for credible product carbon footprints, meaningful supplier engagement, and alignment between product level claims and corporate transition strategies. 

 What is Science Based Targets initiative framework for Forest, Land and Agriculture (SBTi FLAG) 

The Science Based Targets initiative framework for Forest, Land and Agriculture (SBTi FLAG) guidance provides a dedicated framework for setting science-based targets that address emissions and removals from forests, land, and agriculture, alongside a company‚Äôs near-term and long-term climate targets. It clarifies which emissions fall within the FLAG boundary, how land-based emissions and removals should be accounted for, and how companies are expected to demonstrate progress over time in a way that reflects the biological and physical realities of land systems. 

Under the SBTi FLAG, companies are required to set a FLAG-specific target separate from other emissions targets when either of these conditions is met: 

  1. Sector-based requirement: Companies operating in SBTi-designated FLAG sectors, including forest and paper products, food production (animal source), food and beverage processing, food and staples retailing, and tobacco. 
  1. Emissions-threshold requirement: Companies in any sector whose FLAG-related emissions exceed 20% of total gross emissions across scopes 1, 2, and 3. This threshold must be assessed on a gross basis and cannot be netted against removals. 

When a FLAG target is required, companies must report emissions and removals across clearly defined categories that reflect distinct land-based processes: 

  • Land-use change emissions: Refers to CO2 released from carbon stock losses due to the conversion of land between land use categories, such as deforestation for cropland expansion. 
  • Land management emissions: Refers to both CO2 and non-CO2 gases arising from practices within the same land-use category, including tillage, cropping systems, livestock management, and rice cultivation. 
  • Carbon storage and removals: Refers to CO2 removed from the atmosphere through biological processes such as photosynthesis and stored in long-lived biogenic carbon pools such as forest biomass and soils. 

 To ensure transparency and comparability, companies setting FLAG targets are expected to provide disaggregated information that enables meaningful interpretation and review. This includes: 

  •  FLAG emissions and removals reported per commodity and per region 
  •  Separation of land-use change and land management emissions 
  •  Separate reporting of CO2 and non-CO2 emissions from land management activities 
  •  Removals reported by commodity, with further disaggregation across scope 1 and scope 3 categories encouraged 

 These reporting expectations align with the GHG Protocol Land Sector Guidance and the SBTi FLAG Annex submission requirements, supporting consistent and credible treatment of land-based emissions across corporate inventories. 

That‚Äôs where our new SBTi FLAG feature comes in. 

 SAP Sustainability Footprint Management for SBTi FLAG 

To facilitate detailed external reporting, especially frameworks like SBTi FLAG that require specific categorization of impacts, SAP's Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a powerful multi-impact category feature. This enables you to map calculated impact category results directly to relevant reporting categories, ensuring alignment with SBTi FLAG requirements. 

For this use case, the integration and calculation setup follow the same procedure as described in our "Multi-Impact Categories in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management" blog post. For SBTi FLAG, the process utilizes your ERP data to automate activity data collection, map to emission factors for the relevant impact categories, and execute one centralized footprint calculation. The critical difference is ensuring that the relevant impact categories for FLAG are selected during the Footprint Inventory setup. 

Here, you'll define the boundaries and specific impact categories to be assessed in your environmental footprint calculation. This step is crucial for FLAG reporting and the following categories must be selected: 

  • Fossil GHG Emissions from Land Management 
  • Biogenic Non-CO2 Emissions 
  • Land Use Change Biogenic CO2 Emissions 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Removals 

Additionally, Climate Change is always calculated as a mandatory impact category in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management; you can also choose to calculate additional categories, like abiotic resource depletion, in parallel with the FLAG analysis. 

For details, see Manage Footprint Inventory Scopes. 

You also need to ensure the inclusion of impact factors for the relevant categories using the Manage Emission Factors app. Each impact category requires a specific emission/impact factor. When populating either the LCA or Simple Template, input a separate entry for each category, even if they relate to the same product, energy source, or business activity, as they are distinguished by distinct Impact Category IDs. 

For SBTi, you must include the following categories are included via data packages: 

  • Fossil GHG Emissions from Land Management (CCFL) 
  • Biogenic Non-CO2 Emissions (CLCN) 
  • Land Use Change Biogenic CO2 Emissions (CLCLU) 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Emissions (CLCM) 
  • Land Management Biogenic CO2 Removals (RELM) 

Climate Change (CLCH) impact factors must also be added, as this category is always mandatory in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Consuming apps like Manage Purchase Products Footprints, Model Energy Flows, Manage Waste Footprints, or Manage Business Activities will utilize these factors for relevant calculations. 

For detailed guidance on maintaining emission factors data, see Emission Factors Data. You'll find a table under Impact Categories, listing all categories, including their IDs, dimensions, and indicators. 

Aside from the impact categories being reported, other calculation parameters like master data, energy flow models, and periodic data remain unchanged. This ensures you can effortlessly scale calculations across different impact categories, allowing existing setups to smoothly adapt and include these additions 

For analyzing the calculated footprints, the Footprint Overview app offers a high-level summary of your impact calculation results, while the Corporate Balance app provides a consolidated view of your organization‚Äôs environmental performance. The Purchased Products analytics app now allows display of calculated footprints by impact category using a filter option. 

While the initial dashboards emphasize the Climate Change impact category, clicking on them allows for further detailed analysis. See Using the Footprint Overview Application for more information. 

The Corporate Balance app provides an overarching summary of your organization‚Äôs environmental performance. For more on viewing organizational emissions, see Using the Corporate Balance Application. 

The Purchased Products analytics app now provides a detailed understanding of the environmental burden associated with specific procured products across all selected impact categories, offering a richer perspective beyond CO2e. For more insights, see Using the Purchased Products Application. 

Map Calculation Results to Reporting Standards 

The Impact Categories from Sustainability Footprint Management are designed to be standard-agnostic, serving as building blocks for supporting multiple reporting standards simultaneously. This versatility, however, requires final results to be mapped to the appropriate reporting categories for the chosen standard. The following table illustrates this: 

 

ID 

SAP Impact Categories for Climate Change Group  

SBTi FLAG  

Reporting Categories 

CLCH 

Climate Change  

Not applicable, always calculated 

CLCF 

Fossil GHG Emissions 

n/a 

CCFL 

Fossil GHG Emissions from Land Management  

Land Management (non-CO2 emissions)  

CLCB 

Biogenic CO2 Emissions from Combustion  

n/a 

CLCN 

Biogenic Non-CO2 Emissions  

Land Management (non-CO2 emissions) 

CLCLU 

Land Use Change Biogenic CO2 Emissions  

Land Use Change Emissions  

CLCLM 

Land Management Biogenic CO2 Emissions  

Land Management (CO2 emissions) 

RELM 

Land Management Biogenic CO2 Removals

RECCS 

Technological GHG Removal by Direct Capture of Industrial Emissions  

n/a 

REDCC 

Technological GHG Removal by Direct Air Capture  

n/a 

REPCC 

Product Biogenic CO2 Uptake  

n/a

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud: How can I compare variable values?
entry.content:
Hello all,

in SAC I use BW live connection within a story. To read the value of a variable 0S_CUS I use:

var cust = Chart_59.getDataSource().getVariableValues("0S_CUS")[0];

 Then I try to compare the value of variable "cust". Why: I would like to hide some pages in my SAC story if the customer number is greater than 10000000. The infoobject for variable 0S_CUS is 0CUSTOMER (data type: CHAR, length 10).

But this is not working:

var border = "0010000000";
if (cust > border) {
Application.setPageVisible("Page_7", false);
} else {
Application.setPageVisible("Page_7", true);
}

The variable 0S_CUS is a select-option but we pre-fill it with only one value. 

The error is: auto-type conversion isn't supported.

Thanks for your help!

entry.title: A simplified approach to choosing between S/4HANA Public Cloud vs S/4HANA Private Cloud
entry.content:
One of the fundamental decisions that organisations are facing as they plan their transition to Cloud ERP, is the deployment option to chose. In SAP terms the question becomes: Would S/4HANA Private Cloud or S/4HANA Public Cloud be the better choice?

At high level, S/4HANA Private Cloud is a "tailored-to-fit" solution enabling flexibility and customization, while S/4HANA Public Cloud is a "ready-to-run" solution prioritizing standardization and deployment speed. In reality, the selection between the two is more complex with different parameters to consider. This article aims to ease the decision process through a simplified approach.

The right deployment option could, and most often should, be subject to a series of workshops and careful assessment of an organization's specific needs. Still, experience from customer engagements has enabled me to develop a simplified approach which helps provide initial steering.

Overall, where possible, S/4HANA Public Cloud should be the go-to deployment option. This is due to its unique qualities, including faster access to innovation, a simpler Cloud operating model and reduced TCO. On the flip side, Public Cloud also comes with limitations as compared to S/4HANA Private Cloud. These include a narrower implementation scope (worth noting that Public Cloud's scope is more than enough for most organizations), reduced system control (which again may not be a concern for most organizations) and the need to leave customer customisations behind (which could actually benefit an organization's move towards a Clean Core).

To simplify the decision, as a rule of thumb an organisation should opt for S/4HANA Public Cloud if the following three elements match their needs:

  • S/4HANA Public Cloud implementation scope. Public Cloud offers  broad functionality covering the needs of most organizations and is becoming constantly richer in scope. Still, some functionality such as industry-specific scenarios may be unique to Private Cloud. The way to confirm that Public Cloud is fit for purpose is by completing the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment.
  • New implementation as migration option. A migration option to Public Cloud can be completed only via a new implementation, while a migration to Private Cloud can also be completed via a system conversion or Selective Data transition for organizations on a legacy SAP ERP system. If you are new to SAP, then a new implementation is your only way forward and should not be  a consideration. If you are moving from a legacy SAP ERP system though, then it is key to validate that a new implementation is right for you. A new implementation requires that custom code and custom processes from your legacy SAP ERP system are left behind - which could actually be an opportunity for moving to a Clean Core and reinventing business processes using SAP's Best Practices. A new implementation also requires that previous transactional data aka closed items are left behind e.g. archived, otherwise maintained in the legacy ERP system (online as read-only or offline as a backup/image). Unless there is a specific need to bring closed items to the new Cloud ERP environment, leaving these behind helps run a lighter, easier to maintain and more cost-efficient system.
  • Public Cloud Operating model. Public Cloud is equivalent to SaaS, as opposed to Private Cloud which is similar to IaaS/PaaS. This means that Public Cloud is highly standardized, enabling rapid innovation at a lower TCO, offering a Clean Core and SAP‚Äëcontrolled operations and allowing the customer to focus on what matters to them most. It comes with Application Management Services included, therefore, among others, SAP is taking care of  application management including release updates and Middleware. Still, in Public Cloud, extensibility options are limited (classic ABAP extensibility not possible), the customer has no control over release upgrades (these are mandatory without the option to postpone and with a time-restricted regression testing window), and has no control over infrastructure choices either (Hyperscaler selection). Unless the organization has a particular need for any of these or for an operating model of shared responsibility with SAP, then Public Cloud should be the way forward.

While the above three elements focus mostly on the technical aspects of the deployment option decision, it comes without saying that the company's culture is also a major decisive factor. The appetite to reimagine processes and outsource a large part of IT operations to the software vendor while re-focusing on innovation activities, are important elements for a Public Cloud deployment.

To summarise, if you are an organisation planning a transition to SAP‚Äôs Cloud ERP and considering your deployment option, your actionable next steps are as follows: complete the SAP Digital Discovery Assessment to confirm whether the scope of S/4HANA Public Cloud matches your functionality needs, evaluate whether a new implementation is fit for purpose, and assess whether the Public Cloud operating model suits you. If the answer to all three questions is yes, and you have or manage to establish the right company culture, then you should lead with S/4HANA Public Cloud.

Disclaimer: The approach suggested in this article reflects my views based on experience from working with different organizations, rather than SAP's official views. It aims to provide simplified guidelines and initial steering, but does not replace the need for more thorough assessment.
